edge: Farrokh discovers Smile and seeks them out after their performance.
Farrokh meets and is attracted to Mary at the boutique Biba.
Farrokh replaces Tim Staffell as lead singer of Smile, which becomes Queen.
John Deacon joins Queen as their new bassist.
Farrokh changes his name to Freddie Mercury and renames the band Queen.
John Reid books an American tour for Queen.
Paul Prenter manages the daily schedule of Freddie Mercury.
Freddie proposes to Mary, but questions his sexuality.
Queen places extensive effort into recording 'Bohemian Rhapsody' for their fourth studio album, A Night at the Opera.
Executive Ray leaves Queen when they quit EMI.
album 'A Night at the Opera' contains Freddie's hit song 'Bohemian Rhapsody'
executive Ray Foster refuses to release 'Bohemian Rapsody' as the lead single from EMI
Freddie conspires with radio DJ Kenny Everett to debut 'Bohemian Rhapsody' on his programme
despite critical pans, 'Bohemian Rhapsody' becomes a global hit
launching Queen to international superstardom
Freddie calls off the engagement with Mary but remains close friends
tensions arise over Paul's influence on Freddie
Freddie fires Reid without consulting the band, increasing their strain
Freddie is attracted to a waiter named Jim Hutton who tells Freddie to find him when he learns self-acceptance
During a 1982 press conference about the band's album Hot Space, the press bombards Freddie with questions about his health and sexuality. Jim 'Miami' Beach takes over management.
Freddie signs a $4-million solo deal with CBS Records, effectively ending his association with the band
Performed at Live Aid, helped increase donations
Diagnosed with AIDS, requested secrecy
Married and pregnant wife who visits unexpectedly
Last-minute addition to perform at Live Aid
Corrosive influence, gay orgies, fired in retaliation for revealing sexual escapades
Participated in benefit concert Live Aid
Solo album recorded during engagement in drugs and gay orgies with Paul
Effectively broke up the band by signing a $4-million solo deal
Reconciled with Freddie and performed at Live Aid as a last-minute addition
Recorded solo album Mr. Bad Guy in Munich
Freddie died in 1991 from AIDS-related pneumonia at the age of 45.
The Mercury Phoenix Trust was established by Freddie's band Queen and his friend Jim Hutton in 1992 to raise funds for AIDS research.
Freddie remained friends with Mary until his death in 1991.
Freddie had a loving relationship with Jim Hutton during the final years of his life.
